wiki.content:
Miles' 1969 recording bares the name of its guitarist, John McLaughlin. This sessions tracks represented  Mr. Davis' new direction into ampilified music.
        
User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.
wiki.summary: Miles' 1969 recording bares the name of its guitarist, John McLaughlin. This sessions tracks represented  Mr. Davis' new direction into ampilified music.

track.name: John McLaughlin
comments: I always remember being blown away by this album when it first came out. Maybe there is something in Caesarsdream's comment below, but I can still listen to it happily.
wow-have listened to mahavishnu for years but never heard john and miles before-always thought i would not GET it-this is fine stuff-will now look for this disc
John Mclaughlin is the greatest...but this was not near his best in my opinion....in fact this whole album is a bit noisy and boring.
What more can I say about the James Baldwin of music?
Bitches Brew was the first Miles Davis album I bought. It blew me away then and still sounds amazing 40 years later. Miles still rules.

It's named "John McLaughlin" and it's on the CBS Masterpieces 1970 CD2 of Bitches Brew.
On all cuts:Miles,Wayne Shorter,Lenny White,Benny Maupin,Chick Korea,Jim Riley,Jack deJohnette,Harvey Brooks,Charles Alias,David Holland,and John MCLaughlin on electric guitar - playing on Spanish Key,Miles runs the Voodoo down and Pharaoh's Dance. Booklet to Bitches Brew.
ISSUE NUMBER ONE... wait, wrong John McLaughlin.
Miles Dewey Davis.  Never before.  Never again.
this is of course song listed on original LP, side three, disc 2...
my favorite track off an epic album...FTW
damn when was this recorded?  Its sounds Jaki Liebziet on drums
